newsitem.title: USA: Emerging debt prices up as Bulgarian Bradys lead.
newsitem.headline: Emerging debt prices up as Bulgarian Bradys lead.

text.p: Most emerging debt prices ended the New York trading session higher, with Bulgaria outperforming others and major Latin credits tightening 15 to 20 basis points, traders said on Wednesday.
Bullish sentiment continued to propel Bulgaria Brady bonds higher on the heels of the previous session's gains, they said.
At 1700 EST/2200 GMT, Bulgaria's FLRBs were 1-7/8 stronger at 44 bid, and its IABs were 1-1/8 firmer at 56-5/8 bid. The country's discount bonds were 3/4 higher at 60-1/2 bid.
Bulgaria's outgoing Socialists agreed to give an interim cabinet wider powers to negotiate and conclude agreements with international lenders to help pull the country out of its economic crisis.
Among other emerging debt issuers, Russian Vnesh US$ performed well, gaining 1/2 to 83-1/4 bid.

Among Latin credits, Argentine FRBs were quoted 1/8 higher at 91-3/8, Brazilian "C" bonds were 1/2 stronger at 80-1/2 bid, while Mexican pars were 5/8 firmer at 77-1/4 bid. Venezuelan FLIRBs were 1/4 better at 91 bid.
"We saw some decent price action in the major Latin credits: Argentina, Brazil and Mexico....We've seen a lot of money going into those countries," another Brady trader said.
"There's been a lot of demand, not only on the debt side but the equities side," he added.
Among the major credits, Peru and Mexico debt tightened by about 20 basis points, traders said.
"Mexico was catching up....Yesterday it was kind of lagging, and today it caught up with the rest of the countries," one trader said.

In Peru, talks between the government and Marxists hostage-takers are not expected to lead to a quick solution to the crisis. Both sides have agreed to a pact of silence, leaving others to speculate as to what points were discussed during a four-hour meeting held Tuesday.
Regarding Ecuador Bradys, the appointment of Fabian Alarcon as president failed to boost the country's debt amid sluggish activity, traders said.
Ecuadorean bonds posted losses, with par bonds quoted off 7/8 at 45-1/8 bid, and PDI bonds down 1-1/8 at 60-7/8.
"Ecuador has widened....We continue to see some major client liquidations out of there," said one trader.
In the government market, the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond was unchanged at 97-11/32 to yield 6.71 percent at the close.
